none.description: almost perfect recognised transcript (e.g. comma/space/hyphen placement, repeated words, disfluencies)

minor.description: easily able to read through (e.g. incorrect capitalisation, pronouns/prepositions, omission of secondary detail)

standard.description: disrupts the flow and comprehension (e.g. misrecognised/omitted names, homophones/sound-alikes, omission of primary detail)

serious.description: misinformation which changes meaning (e.g. alternative names/numbers, incorrect word endings/contractions, omission causing misinformation)

examples.reference: Um, um, yes I am um very happy to see you.
examples.recognised: Um, yes I am very happy to see you.
examples.reason: There are missing disfluences but output more readble so this shouldn't be penalised

examples.reference: I don't believe an executive should be able to overturn a decision.
examples.recognised: I don't believe in executive should be able to overturn a decision.
examples.reason: The word an has been substitued with in which is an incorrect use of a preposition

examples.reference: Ra'Shede Hageman, a top defensive tackle prospect...
examples.recognised: Rash eared haggard man, a top defensive tackle prospect...
examples.reason: The name Ra'Shede Hageman has been misrecognised by words that soundalike

examples.reference: This has been confirmed by the Pentagon.
examples.recognised: This hasn't been confirmed by the Pentagon.
examples.reason: The word has is reversed which causes misinformation about the message
